items.title: Why does SSH support only 1024 bit DSA keys in 3.0?
items.body:
Is there a reason why the ssh serialization module does not support DSA keys with a bit length greater than 1024 in cryptography version 3.0? I could not find any information in the corresponding PR (https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/pull/5146), git log or changelog.

These are the relevant lines that were released in 3.0.

https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/blob/143f56f65cd4c78eecdd9f09fa8e0e806f01c203/src/cryptography/hazmat/primitives/serialization/ssh.py#L330-L333


And here is a serialization/deserialization snippet that worked fine on cryptography 2.9 but raises said ValueError in 3.0:

```python
from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.serialization import (load_ssh_public_key,
        Encoding, PublicFormat)
from cryptography.hazmat.backends import default_backend
from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.asymmetric.dsa import generate_private_key

# Create DSA key pair with key size != 1024
dsa_key = generate_private_key(key_size=2048, backend=default_backend())

# Dump to SSH
ssh_bytes = dsa_key.public_key().public_bytes(Encoding.OpenSSH, PublicFormat.OpenSSH)

# Parse from SSH
dsa_key_parsed = load_ssh_public_key(ssh_bytes, backend=default_backend()) # BREAKS ON v3.0

# Assert that no public key info was lost in serialization
assert dsa_key.public_key().public_numbers() == dsa_key_parsed.public_numbers()
```


Context: 
The update just broke some test code in a project I maintain (https://github.com/secure-systems-lab/securesystemslib/pull/261). I'm fine in changing the test code, I just wanted to know if the change was intentional? Thanks! :)

(cc @markokr, @reaperhulk, @joshuagl)

items.title: [cryptography==3.0] Python 2 deprecation done wrong
items.body:
So after the upgrade, pytest started failing with `CryptographyDeprecationWarning` under Python 2.
I believe this is expected. What's not expected is that it's hard to filter this error.

Because it's a custom class that is part of the project, trying to apply `-W` or `filterwarnings = ignore::cryptography.utils.CryptographyDeprecationWarning` in pytest makes it explode (https://github.com/pytest-dev/pytest/issues/7524) because in order to filter out a warning, it should first get imported but that import itself emits the warning. It's a chicken-egg problem:
```console
$ python27 -W ignore::cryptography.utils.CryptographyDeprecationWarning
Invalid -W option ignored: invalid module name: 'cryptography.utils'
Python 2.7.15 (default, Sep 25 2018, 19:19:39) 
[GCC 7.3.0] on linux2
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import cryptography
.tox/py27/lib/python2.7/site-packages/cryptography/__init__.py:39: CryptographyDeprecationWarning: Python 2 is no longer supported by the Python core team. Support for it is now deprecated in cryptography, and will be removed in a future release.
  CryptographyDeprecationWarning,
```

As you can see, implementing a warning when its own import causes it is not the best idea.

This could be improved by using a native warning that comes with CPython.

Alright, I thought, I can use a parent class to ignore this thing. It's not great that it's probably too broad but what could go wrong, right?

Turns out that the deprecation warning is not a deprecation warning but a user warning. And there's no hints to this in the changelog or in the warning name. This is not cool.

Again, it could be improved by either using a built-in warning or, at least, applying multiple inheritance and using both `UserWarning` and `DeprecationWarning` as a base. This would make the consumer side of the problem so much easier.

And the last thing -- `warnings.warn()` call could be improved by adding something like `stacklevel=2` so that it does not point to `cryptography` internals but rather to the importing module.

If you're open to improving any of the above, tell me and I'll try to find time to contribute a PR.

items.title: [Feature Request] Non-compact-representation of ECDH
items.body:
While learning [how to implement ECIES](https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/issues/4093) I stumbled acress a degree of freedom you have when you use ECDH to get the data for KDF. ECDH has a compact and a full representation. This is because ECDH basicly is a multiplication of a skalar (senders private key) and a vector (receivers public key). As a result, you get a vector, reads: x and y.

cryptographys implementation returns just x. This seems to be absolutely ok: as stated in RFC 6090 this is called ["compact reprsentation" and is as secure as the full representation](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6090#section-4.2).

There are other libraries which use the full representation. For sake of interoperability I think it would be a good idea to (optionally) support full representation, too.

Side-quesion, by the way: is using the x coordinate only really as secure as using the full vector, or is there any current research which prooves the RFC statement wrong?

items.title: Document openssl-compatible symmetric encryption
items.body:
The example in the docs is very easy to follow:
https://cryptography.io/en/latest/hazmat/primitives/symmetric-encryption/#cryptography.hazmat.primitives.ciphers.Cipher
```python
import os
from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.ciphers import Cipher, algorithms, modes
from cryptography.hazmat.backends import default_backend
backend = default_backend()
key = os.urandom(32)
iv = os.urandom(16)
cipher = Cipher(algorithms.AES(key), modes.CBC(iv), backend=backend)
encryptor = cipher.encryptor()
ct = encryptor.update(b"a secret message") + encryptor.finalize()
```

So, I save these values to a file:
```python
with open("key.bin", "wb") as f:
    f.write(key)

with open("ciphertext.enc", "wb") as f:
    f.write(ct)
```

When I try to decrypt the resulting output with `openssl` I get errors:
```bash
$ openssl enc -d -aes-256-cbc -kfile key.bin -in ciphertext.enc --nosalt
*** WARNING : deprecated key derivation used.
Using -iter or -pbkdf2 would be better.
bad decrypt
4546301376:error:06065064:digital envelope routines:EVP_DecryptFinal_ex:bad decrypt:crypto/evp/evp_enc.c:583:
```

I think I must be doing something wrong regarding the IV, salt, encoding (binary/hex), etc. Since this library uses `openssl` under the hood I figure it must be possible to generate an `openssl` compatible output!

Thanks.

items.title: Req: add support for "Subject Information Access" X509v3 extension
items.body:
WRT #1947:

> There's also a set of extensions we've chosen not to implement at all until users ask for them:
>
> [...]
>
> - [ ] Subject Information Access (same as AIA)
>
> [...]

I'd like to "officially" make a request support for the "Subject Information Access" extension described in [RFC 5280, section 4.2.2.2](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5280#section-4.2.2.2):

>  The subject information access extension indicates how to access information and services for the subject of the certificate in which the extension appears. When the subject is a CA, information and services may include certificate validation services and CA policy data. When the subject is an end entity, the information describes the type of services offered and how to access them. In this case, the contents of this extension are defined in the protocol specifications for the supported services. This extension may be included in end entity or CA certificates. Conforming CAs MUST mark this extension as non-critical.

As mentioned in #1947 (and quoted above), SIA is nearly identical to AIA:

```
id-pe-authorityInfoAccess OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= { id-pe 1 }

    AuthorityInfoAccessSyntax  ::=
        SEQUENCE SIZE (1..MAX) OF AccessDescription

    AccessDescription  ::=  SEQUENCE {
        accessMethod          OBJECT IDENTIFIER,
        accessLocation        GeneralName  }
```

```
id-pe-subjectInfoAccess OBJECT IDENTIFIER ::= { id-pe 11 }

    SubjectInfoAccessSyntax  ::=
        SEQUENCE SIZE (1..MAX) OF AccessDescription

    AccessDescription  ::=  SEQUENCE {
        accessMethod          OBJECT IDENTIFIER,
        accessLocation        GeneralName  }
```

In an attempt to narrow the scope of this request to fit my actual use case (since there have apparently been zero requests for support for the SIA extension in the last five years!), I am specifically interested in the ability to create a new X.509v3 certificate containing this extension (OID `1.3.6.1.5.5.7.1.11`) with (multiple instances of) the"`id-ad-caRepository`" (OID `1.3.6.1.5.5.7.48.5`) "`accessMethod`" pointing to different HTTP URIs ("`uniformResourceIdentifier`").

Thanks for your consideration!

items.title: [WINDOWS/OTHERS ?] Cryptography not working in embedded zip
items.body:
Hi,
For the project I'm working (WAPT) we want to use cryptography in a site-packages zip (because we deploy agents and the deployment can be faster with only one zip than multiple copy of files). Python can't loads DLLs/PYDs directly from the zip so I moved them in a DLLs directory which is in the path (he is declared in a python3X._pth). The problem is that you use relative imports for the PYDs : 
_padding.pyd
_openssl.pyd
If I change them to absolute imports it works (for ex : "from cryptography.hazmat.bindings._openssl import ffi, lib" --> "from _openssl import ffi, lib"). I think there is the same problem in others platforms :)

Would it be possible to integrate this changes in the next release? I you want I can make a PR

Lines concerned for Windows : 
https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/blob/63d337e5cc01c026e16b51a1c0b7aba40d9108ef/src/cryptography/hazmat/primitives/padding.py#L13
https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/blob/63d337e5cc01c026e16b51a1c0b7aba40d9108ef/src/cryptography/hazmat/bindings/openssl/binding.py#L14

items.title: FIPS 140-2 Compliant CSPRNG random bytes method
items.body:
Please forgive the duplication if this has been handled before. I searched the issue archives and didn't find a definitive answer. I did see a number of FIPS issues around the replacing of the OpenSSL's RAND engine. This issue is not directly related to the engine. I have a work-around for the engine at runtime. This issue is specifically related to the inability to use the Cryptography library to generate random values to allow for compartmentalized support of FIPS 140-2 compliance within the library.

The Cryptography library documentation refers to `os.urandom` for getting random bytes. The problem with this approach is package installs. To keep a regular and semi-automated patching rhythm, package installs are absolutely preferred. The package installs of Python 3 for Fedora/CentOS are built without FIPS support regardless of the OS FIPS support and require source builds to enable. A fully compartmentalized solution within the Cryptography is definitely preferred to building Python from source.

My underlying driver for this work is the need for a FIPS 140-2 compliant JOSE library and in the future a FIPS 140-2 complaint COSE library for WebAuthn and CTAP. I am currently working on adding JSON Web Encryption (JWE) to the python-jose library.  JWE utilizes key wrap methodologies which needs randomly generated keys and IVs. As python-jose supports multiple cryptographic libraries, I am compartmentalizing random number generation to the libraries themselves. I can get random bytes using some methods that are not exposed in the Cryptography backend to call OpenSSL RAND_bytes but that is not a good idea in most cases and especially not in an OSS library. What would be preferable is to expose a method in hazmat to get random bytes via the RAND engine in OpenSSL.

If pyca accepts that my request is reasonable and in the best interest of the Cryptography library, I would gladly contribute the code change with a small bit of direction around where the function should be placed in hazmat.

items.title: ECDSA signatures variable r and s length
items.body:
I see strange behavior of ECDSA signatures.

ECDSA signature is a TLV tree with `r` and `s`. When `r`s or `s`s high-order bit in the `1` state - needs to add external 0x00 byte to the sequence. Without this byte - signature is wrong.
attached piece of code sometimes raise an error, sometimes no...

looks like somewhere inside `r` and `s` is converted to signed number and all the problems because of that(

Or maybe it not wrong? and always needs to add 0x00?

here colab notebook:
https://colab.research.google.com/drive/1u8Wo_E5VgIA3jQIPvZh0W_oM_WvwTFvA?usp=sharing

raw code:
```
from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.asymmetric import ec
from cryptography.hazmat.primitives import hashes
from cryptography.hazmat.backends import default_backend
from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.asymmetric import utils


private_key = ec.generate_private_key(ec.SECP256R1(), default_backend())
data = b"Sign me please"
signature = private_key.sign(data,ec.ECDSA(hashes.SHA256()))

rlen = signature[3]
r = signature[4:4+rlen]
s = signature[3 + rlen + 3:]
if len(r) == 0x21 and r[0] == 0x00:
    r = r[1:]
if len(s) == 0x21 and s[0] == 0x00:
    s = s[1:]
signature2 = b"\x30\x44\x02\x20" + r + b"\x02\x20" + s

pub = private_key.public_key()

#OK
pub.verify(signature, data, ec.ECDSA(hashes.SHA256()))
#sometimes ERROR sometimes OK
pub.verify(signature2, data, ec.ECDSA(hashes.SHA256()))

print("------------------- OK ---------------------")
```

items.title: [Feature request] Allow Choice Of Symmetric Cipher
items.body:
Python 3.8.3, cryptography 2.9.x

In class [cryptography.hazmat.primitives.asymmetric.rsa.RSAPrivateKeyWithSerialization](https://cryptography.io/en/latest/hazmat/primitives/asymmetric/rsa/#cryptography.hazmat.primitives.asymmetric.rsa.RSAPrivateKeyWithSerialization), this function:

    [private_bytes(encoding, format, encryption_algorithm)](https://cryptography.io/en/latest/hazmat/primitives/asymmetric/rsa/#cryptography.hazmat.primitives.asymmetric.rsa.RSAPrivateKeyWithSerialization.private_bytes)

...allows either _BestAvailableEncryption_ or _NoEncryption_ for its encryption_algorithm parameter.  This feature request is to allow the specification of other ciphers since the best one ["may change over time."](https://cryptography.io/en/latest/hazmat/primitives/asymmetric/serialization/#cryptography.hazmat.primitives.serialization.BestAvailableEncryption)  Allowing one to choose a cipher will prevent undesired surprises to users if/when that encrypt cipher changes.

## load_ssh_public_key
```python
from cryptography.hazmat.backends import default_backend
from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.serialization import load_ssh_public_key

key=open("/home/vagrant/.ssh/id_rsa.pub")
keyval=key.read();
print(type(keyval))
print(keyval)
load_ssh_public_key(keyval, default_backend());
```

### Output
```
<class 'str'>
ssh-rsa  vagrant@kali

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/lib/python3/dist-packages/cryptography/hazmat/primitives/serialization/ssh.py", line 18, in load_ssh_public_key
    key_parts = data.split(b' ', 2)
TypeError: must be str or None, not bytes
```

Thought tests added for https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/issues/2199 would have caught this, so this could very well be a problem between the keyboard and chair.

items.title: malloc: Incorrect checksum for freed object / CRYPTO_free / openssl.abi3.so / SSL_CTX_load_verify_locations
items.body:
Hello,

under Catalina 10.15.4 with debug kernel, using a thread heavy (up to 60 threads) custom addon for mitmproxy, under reasonable but repeated load using a script opening pages in a loop.
Calling SSL_CTX_load_verify_locations is part of the standard mitmproxy function and is performed frequently.
After 24h / 48h this triggers a malloc: Incorrect checksum for freed object and thread crash as below.

The reason why I'm using a debug kernel is that with the release kernel, the same code triggers a kernel panic "invalid waitq". I don't have proof that the 2 problems are related though, I've yet to capture the proper backtrace for the kernel panic.

Does this issue belong to the cryptography project or to openssl ?

Regards,




Exception Type:        EXC_CRASH (SIGABRT)

Exception Note:        EXC_CORPSE_NOTIFY

abort() called

items.title: cryptography/hazmat/bindings/_openssl.abi3.so: undefined symbol: pthread_atfork
items.body:
Hello, 

Found on Linux Synology_DS 3.2.40 #24922 Mon Aug 19 12:09:30 CST 2019 armv7l GNU/Linux synology_armada370_213j

Python 3.7.1 with cryptography 2.9.2, pip 20.1.1, cffi 1.14.0, setuptools 46.4.o

Installed with pip install 
  or
compiled with python3 setup.py build

```
python3 -c "from cryptography.hazmat.bindings._openssl import ffi"
File "<string>", line 1, in <module>
ImportError: /opt/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/cryptography-2.9.2-py3.7-linux-armv7l.egg/cryptography/hazmat/bindings/_openssl.abi3.so: undefined symbol: pthread_atfork
```

Seems to be the same as #5084 but can't find the reason, as that was addressed, any hint?

Thanks

items.title: pip install fancyimpute
items.body: a) If you're filing a bug (as opposed to a feature request), please try the following things: * Upgrade to the latest version of ``setuptools`` and ``pip`` * Make sure you're on a supported version of OpenSSL * Try with the latest version of ``cryptography`` If none of that works, please make sure to include the following information in your bug report: * Versions of Python, ``cryptography``, ``cffi``, ``pip``, and ``setuptools`` you're using * How you installed ``cryptography`` * Clear steps for reproducing your bug Please do not report security issues on Github! Follow the instructions in our documentation for reporting security issues: https://cryptography.io/en/latest/security/

items.title: Adding new ciphers
items.body: Hello, first off I would like to say that this is not an issue but a question. I am working on a project that requires me to add ciphers that do not currently exist in cryptography. I would just like to know how I should go about doing this. Should I start with pyopenssl or cryptography?

items.title: Appending and ecrypting a file with AES CTR
items.body:
Hello All,

This is not an issue but request for help.

I need some help and advice regarding encrypting a file and appending to it. Basically my application receives data in chunks which I have to encrypt and write to a file. So with each data chunk received, I encrypt it and append to the file. I chose AES CTR as the encryption algo. Since the file is encrypted, I need to seek to end of file and update the AES encryptor. To get the counter to point to correct block value I am using something like below:

```
last_block_offset = 16 * (filesize // 16)  # the offset of the last block, 16 is AES block length
encryptor.update(b'\x00' * last_block_offset)  # adjust the counter
encryptor.write(data)
```

This works fine for small files but as the file size increase and last_block_offset becomes bigger, the encryptor.update(b'\x00' * last_block_offset) takes longer time and more space to run.

Is there any other way to update the counter without needing to encrypt all the zero bytes?

Any idea or help is very much appreciated.

Thanks

items.title: DTLS fragment setup failed
items.body:
I am using aiortc to WebRTC communication, which depends on cryptography. During DTLS handshake the DTLS package is larger than MTU (1500), so we want to fragment in DTLS, but it failed by setting this:

```
# SSL init
self.__ctx = certificate._create_ssl_context()

ssl = lib.SSL_new(self.__ctx)
self.ssl = ffi.gc(ssl, lib.SSL_free)

# Disable automatic MTU discovery.
lib.SSL_CTX_set_options(self.__ctx, lib.SSL_OP_NO_QUERY_MTU);
# Set MTU of datagrams so it fits in an UDP packet.
lib.SSL_set_mtu(self.__ctx, 1200)  # ERROR: AttributeError: module 'lib' has no attribute 'SSL_set_mtu'
```


How to setup DTLS fragment of the library? Thanks:)

items.title: Failed Building Wheel for Cryptography
items.body:
Issue
---
I tried installing raftos that uses cryptography and it always gives me a "failed building wheel for cryptography" error. I used different Python versions and it doesn't work. Does anyone have an idea why? I am using Windows and Python 3.7.7. in this case.

items.title: X509 can't load " TRUSTED CERTIFICATE "s
items.body:
Environment:
* MacOS Catalina 10.15.3 (19D76)
* Python 3.6.10
* **cryptography 2.9.2**
* cffi 1.14.0
* pip 20.0.2
* pycparser 2.20
* setuptools 46.1.3
* six 1.14.0
* wheel 0.34.2
* OpenSSL compatibility version 1.0.0, current version 1281.0.0

I have an issue loading certificates wrapped in `-----BEGIN TRUSTED CERTIFICATE-----` and `-----END TRUSTED CERTIFICATE-----` with `x509.load_pem_x509_certificate()`.

When I do so it returns the following error:

```pytb
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./toto.py", line 39, in <module>
    load_pem_x509_certificate(bytes(cert, 'utf-8'), default_backend())
  File "/Users/fabricemarie/.local/share/virtualenvs/toto/lib/python3.6/site-packages/cryptography/x509/base.py", line 52, in load_pem_x509_certificate
    return backend.load_pem_x509_certificate(data)
  File "/Users/fabricemarie/.local/share/virtualenvs/toto/lib/python3.6/site-packages/cryptography/hazmat/backends/openssl/backend.py", line 1223, in load_pem_x509_certificate
    "Unable to load certificate. See https://cryptography.io/en/la"
ValueError: Unable to load certificate. See https://cryptography.io/en/latest/faq/#why-can-t-i-import-my-pem-file for more details.
```

It works as expected after replacing:
* `-----BEGIN TRUSTED CERTIFICATE-----` with `-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE-----` and
* `-----END TRUSTED CERTIFICATE-----` with `-----END CERTIFICATE-----`

Example of a random CA that I was trying to load (found in the Linux trusted rootCAs bundle):
```
-----BEGIN TRUSTED CERTIFICATE-----
MIIH0zCCBbugAwIBAgIIXsO3pkN/pOAwDQYJKoZIhvcNAQEFBQAwQjESMBAGA1UE

```

OpenSSL indeed opens them without modification:
```Shell
$ x509 -in /tmp/trusted_debug.crt -noout -fingerprint
SHA1 Fingerprint=93:05:7A:88:15:C6:4F:CE:88:2F:FA:91:16:52:28:78:BC:53:64:17
```

It's ok not to support it I guess, but I suggest that the FAQ over at <https://cryptography.io/en/latest/faq/#why-can-t-i-import-my-pem-file> be modified accordingly to give a hint to the user.

items.title: p must be exactly 1024, 2048, or 3072 bits long
items.body:
Hi, I'm getting an error while downloading files from SFTP using pysftp. The source of the error is due to the limitation of the number of bits the parameters can take on the cryptography package.

The source of the issue in the below method in **cryptography\hazmat\primitives\asymmetric\dsa.py**

`def _check_dsa_parameters(parameters):
    if parameters.p.bit_length() not in [1024, 2048, 3072, **4096**]:
        raise ValueError("p must be exactly 1024, 2048, or 3072 bits long")
    if parameters.q.bit_length() not in [160, 224, 256]:
        raise ValueError("q must be exactly 160, 224, or 256 bits long")    
    if not (1 < parameters.g < parameters.p):
        raise ValueError("g, p don't satisfy 1 < g < p.")`

https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/blob/master/src/cryptography/hazmat/primitives/asymmetric/dsa.py ... line no 131

By adding the 4096 bits in the bit length check fixed the issue. Can you please make this fix in the library.

python 3.6
cryptography 2.9.2
pip 20.0.2
setuptools 46.1.3

Used requirements.txt to install Cryptography
`cryptography==2.9.2`

Please let me know if you need any additional details.

items.title: ImportError No module named 'cryptography' on Docker Alpine
items.body:
Hi! I get an error ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'cryptography' on import. I cannot import cryptography lib as well as other libs which have cryptography as a dependency. 

My docker file
```

FROM nickgryg/alpine-pandas:3.7.7 as base
FROM base as builder

RUN pip install --upgrade pip

RUN mkdir /install
RUN apk update && apk add postgresql-dev gcc musl-dev python3-dev libffi-dev openssl-dev 
WORKDIR /install
COPY requirements.txt /requirements.txt
RUN pip install --install-option="--prefix=/install" -r /requirements.txt
FROM base
COPY --from=builder /install /usr/local
COPY src /app
RUN apk --no-cache add libpq 
WORKDIR /app
```

requirements.txt is below
```

certifi==2020.4.5.1
chardet==3.0.4
Django==3.0.3

idna==2.9
pandas==1.0.3

I also tried to add line add apk py3-cryptography to dockerfile but that didn't help.

I found many questions related to issues with cryptography but no solutions helped. 

Please help to resolve this

items.title: OpenSSL binaries shipped with 2.9.1 wheels fail to load on macOS High Sierra
items.body:
Installation and importing work as expected. But once the OpenSSL backend is actually loaded, an exception is raised due to a missing symbol `____chkstk_darwin`. Based on some similar issues I found, this seems like an ABI compatibility issue [[1]](https://github.com/google/jax/issues/1782)[[2]](https://github.com/nodegui/nodegui/issues/391)[[3]](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/58426186/dyld-symbol-not-found-chkstk-darwin).

During packaging, if I understand correctly seems the shipped version of OpenSSL is pulled via brew [[4]](https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/runs/605760341?check_suite_focus=true#step:4:7). This seems to pull in a Catalina-specific variant of the library. A possible solution then could be to force usage of a bottle for the earliest-supported macOS version, but I'm unsure (a) how to do this and (b) if there are issues that would arise from doing so.

Not sure what the best approach for testing such a fix is. Since the pipelines all run on Catalina, manual testing is required (which I can do easily enough). But I'm not sure how to run a pipeline that generates a wheel artifact to test.

# Software versions:

* `python`: 3.6.8
* `cryptography`: 2.9.1
* `cffi`: 1.14.0
* `pip`: 18.1
* `setuptools`: 40.6.2

## macOS

```
ProductName:    Mac OS X
ProductVersion: 10.13.6
BuildVersion:   17G12034
```

# Installation method

Standard pip install. Pulls in `cryptography-2.9.1-cp35-abi3-macosx_10_9_x86_64.whl`.

# Steps to reproduce

Take this script as an example:

```python
from cryptography.hazmat.backends import default_backend

default_backend()
```

2.9.0 release:

```
$ pip install cryptography==2.9.0
$ python repro.py  # status code 0
```

2.9.1 release:

```
$ pip install cryptography==2.9.1
$ python repro.py
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "repro.py", line 3, in <module>
    default_backend()
  File "/Users/vida/tmp-venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/cryptography/hazmat/backends/__init__.py", line 15, in default_backend
    from cryptography.hazmat.backends.openssl.backend import backend
  File "/Users/vida/tmp-venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/cryptography/hazmat/backends/openssl/__init__.py", line 7, in <module>
    from cryptography.hazmat.backends.openssl.backend import backend
  File "/Users/vida/tmp-venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/cryptography/hazmat/backends/openssl/backend.py", line 75, in <module>
    from cryptography.hazmat.bindings.openssl import binding
  File "/Users/vida/tmp-venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/cryptography/hazmat/bindings/openssl/binding.py", line 16, in <module>
    from cryptography.hazmat.bindings._openssl import ffi, lib
ImportError: dlopen(/Users/vida/tmp-venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/cryptography/hazmat/bindings/_openssl.abi3.so, 2): Symbol not found: ____chkstk_darwin
  Referenced from: /Users/vida/tmp-venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/cryptography/hazmat/bindings/_openssl.abi3.so
  Expected in: /usr/lib/libSystem.B.dylib
 in /Users/vida/tmp-venv/lib/python3.6/site-packages/cryptography/hazmat/bindings/_openssl.abi3.so
```

items.title: Downloadable files in PYPI - 2.9.1
items.body:
I've been encountering some installation errors since the release of 2.9.1. It seems like the whl's are no longer being distributed. Is this intentional?

Downloadable files for 2.9.1: https://pypi.org/project/cryptography/2.9.1/#files
Downloadable files for 2.9.0: https://pypi.org/project/cryptography/2.9/#files

items.title: OpenSSL 1.1.1g
items.body:
- [x] Windows
    - [x] Send a pull request to `pyca/infra` updating the [version and hash](https://github.com/pyca/infra/blob/master/.github/workflows/build-openssl.yml#L36-L37)
    - [x] Wait for it to be merged
    - [x] Wait for the Github Actions job to complete
- [x] macOS
    - [x] Send a pull request to `homebrew` upgrading the `openssl@1.1` formula
    - [x] Wait for it to be merged
- [x] manylinux
    - [x] Send a pull request to `pyca/infra` updating the [version and hash](https://github.com/pyca/infra/blob/master/cryptography-manylinux/install_openssl.sh#L5-L6) for `manylinux`
    - [x] Wait for it to be merged
    - [x] Wait for the Github Actions job to complete
- [x] Changelog entry

items.title: Undefined symbol "OPENSSL_no_config"
items.body:
Hi,

 Trying to use a module that uses the crypto package I get `ImportError: /usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/cryptography/hazmat/bindings/_openssl.abi3.so: Undefined symbol "OPENSSL_no_config"`. Seems like in newer versions of openssl OPENSSL_no_config was deprecated in favour of OPENSSL_init.

Related info:

**OS version**: FreeBSD 11.3-RELEASE #0 r349754: Fri Jul  5 04:45:24 UTC 2019

**Cryptography version**: cryptography==2.9
**cffi version**: cffi==1.14.0
**OpenSSL version**: OpenSSL 1.0.2s-freebsd  28 May 2019
**PIP version**: pip 20.0.2 
**setuptools version**: setuptools 44.0.0 

Used pip to install cryptography. To reproduce the issue use the mentioned OS. Install the official openssl & pip versions and attempt to run http3server from: https://github.com/aiortc/aioquic.

items.title: unstructuredName in CSR
items.body:
I'm moving my code from shell scripts using `openssl` CLI to Cryptography.

Great experience by the way, I want to mention the documentation is excellent and the examples very useful.

Anyway, in my current code, I have two attributes that I use that are not part of the CSR subject :

`unstructuredName` and `challengePassword`

I'm not sure how to move these over to Cryptography, I was able to find useful informations on StackOverflow [here](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/54202632/openssl-optionalcompanyname-optional-company-name-in-command), but I still don't see how to implement. I'm not even sure they are used, but it's possible some CA requires it.

Thanks !

If you're filing a bug (as opposed to a feature request), please try the
following things:

* Upgrade to the latest version of ``setuptools`` and ``pip``
* Make sure you're on a supported version of OpenSSL
* Try with the latest version of ``cryptography``

If none of that works, please make sure to include the following information in
your bug report:

* Versions of Python, ``cryptography``, ``cffi``, ``pip``, and ``setuptools``
  you're using
* How you installed ``cryptography``
* Clear steps for reproducing your bug

Please do not report security issues on Github! Follow the instructions in our
documentation for reporting security issues:
https://cryptography.io/en/latest/security/

items.title: AES-ECB won't initialize due to probable bug in the validation code
items.body:
Apologies if this is due to my misuse and not an actual bug in the code!

My code: 
```
cipher = Cipher(algorithms.AES(key), modes.ECB, backend=backend)
```

Error message:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "p7.py", line 12, in <module>
    cipher = Cipher(algorithms.AES(key), modes.ECB, backend=backend)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/cryptography/hazmat/primitives/ciphers/base.py", line 108, in __init__
    mode.validate_for_algorithm(algorithm)
TypeError: _check_aes_key_length() missing 1 required positional argument: 'algorithm'
```
I think there's something going on with [assigning the function to another function like this](https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/blob/55f3b7d71b448c5a7f4dd98acfc6f349412bc934/src/cryptography/hazmat/primitives/ciphers/modes.py#L125), and with how Python handles self? I am reasonably sure this could be fixed by changing this line to the following.
```
def validate_for_algorithm(self, algorithm):
    _check_aes_key_length(self, algorithm)
```

thanks

items.title: ImportError: RSA_get0_crt_params: symbol not found
items.body:
### Issue

After upgrading to cryptography 2.9 I get the following import failure:
```
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/vlab_inf_common/vmware/virtual_machine.py", line 11, in <module>
    import OpenSSL
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/OpenSSL/__init__.py", line 8, in <module>
    from OpenSSL import crypto, SSL
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/OpenSSL/crypto.py", line 15, in <module>
    from OpenSSL._util import (
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/OpenSSL/_util.py", line 6, in <module>
    from cryptography.hazmat.bindings.openssl.binding import Binding
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/cryptography/hazmat/bindings/openssl/binding.py", line 16, in <module>
    from cryptography.hazmat.bindings._openssl import ffi, lib
ImportError: Error relocating /usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/cryptography/hazmat/bindings/_openssl.abi3.so: RSA_get0_crt_params: symbol not found
```

If I downgrade to cryptography 2.8, everything works as expected.

### Version info
OS - Alpine 3.7
Python - 3.6.9
Pip - 20.0.2
cffi - 1.14.0
setuptools - 40.6.2

### Repro steps
I'm building all of this via Docker. If you build the following image and attempt to import the `OpenSSL` package you can reproduce the issue:

```
FROM alpine:3.7
RUN apk update && apk upgrade
RUN apk add wget python3 python3-dev postgresql-dev openssl gcc g++ \
            linux-headers libc-dev libffi-dev pcre pcre-dev make
RUN wget https://bootstrap.pypa.io/get-pip.py && python3 get-pip.py --trusted-host pypi.org
RUN pip install cryptography==2.9 pyopenssl
CMD python3
```

items.title: EllipticCurvePublicKey can't be serialized to raw format
items.body:
Is there a particular reason not to support raw format (`serialization.PublicFormat.Raw` and `serialization.Encoding.Raw`) (x || y in big endian) to serialize an `ec.EllipticCurvePublicKey` like so:
```
assert(isinstance(public_key, ec.EllipticCurvePublicKey))
public_bytes = public_key.public_bytes(
    encoding=serialization.Encoding.Raw,
    format=serialization.PublicFormat.Raw
)
```

Indeed, that is easily achieved using something like that:
```
pn = public_key.public_numbers()
public_bytes = pn.x.to_bytes(32, byteorder='big') + pn.y.to_bytes(32, byteorder='big')
```

I think it is quite common to serialize a public key to the raw format. I am willing to make a PR if you think it makes sense to include raw format.

items.title: ED448 and ED25519 restriction to OpenSSL 1.1.1b+
items.body:
Hey,

I am trying to figure out why the restriction to limit ed448 and ed25519 to OpenSSL 1.1.1b and later was put into cryptography:

- The commit cd05e2ac5b8336dac78a0dd73ec9a7baa06208c6 that introduced does not give a reason
- The [OpenSSL changelog](https://www.openssl.org/news/cl111.txt) does list anything related to ed448 or ed25519 
- I modified the code and at least on Ubuntu 18.04 with OpenSSL, key creation, CSR generation and certificate signing using EdDSA works fine.

So I wondering if I am missing something or should make a PR to change the 1.1.1b requirement to 1.1.1

items.title: Failure to parse a valid X.509 certificate
items.body:
* Versions of Python, ``cryptography``, ``cffi``, ``pip``, and ``setuptools``
  you're using
  * cryptography: 2.8
  * cffi: 1.11.5
  * pip: 20.0.2
  * setuptools: 40.8.0
* How you installed ``cryptography``
`pip3 install cryptography`
* Clear steps for reproducing your bug

This problem is easily reproducible and depending on specific data on a X.509 certificate.
Example code is trivial:
```python
from cryptography import x509
from cryptography.hazmat.backends import default_backend

st_cert = open('ftp.gijonfilmfestival.com-pem.cer', 'rb').read()
cert = x509.load_pem_x509_certificate(st_cert, default_backend())
cert.extensions
```

Emitted ValueError:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/usr/local/lib64/python3.7/site-packages/cryptography/utils.py", line 170, in inner
    result = func(instance)
  File "/usr/local/lib64/python3.7/site-packages/cryptography/hazmat/backends/openssl/x509.py", line 127, in extensions
    self._backend, self._x509
  File "/usr/local/lib64/python3.7/site-packages/cryptography/hazmat/backends/openssl/decode_asn1.py", line 249, in parse
    "parsed".format(oid)
ValueError: The <ObjectIdentifier(oid=1.3.6.1.5.5.7.48.1.5, name=OCSPNoCheck)> extension is invalid and can't be parsed
```

Looking at the decoded ASN.1, the sequence simply has no data in it. That's because RFC 6960 in _4.2.2.2.1.  Revocation Checking of an Authorized Responder_ specifies following: 

> A CA may specify that an OCSP client can trust a responder for the
> lifetime of the responder's certificate.  The CA does so by
> including the extension id-pkix-ocsp-nocheck.  This SHOULD be a
> non-critical extension.  The value of the extension SHALL be NULL.

Code in `_X509ExtensionParser.parse()` (https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/blob/master/src/cryptography/hazmat/backends/openssl/decode_asn1.py#L245) assumes NULL value to be an error. In this particular case, it is not.

Suggested patch:
```
--- "cryptography/hazmat/backends/openssl/decode_asn1 - orig.py"        2020-02-11 20:45:23.438356100 +0200
+++ cryptography/hazmat/backends/openssl/decode_asn1.py 2020-03-14 10:30:37.076339000 +0200
@@ -243,11 +243,12 @@
             else:
                 ext_data = backend._lib.X509V3_EXT_d2i(ext)
                 if ext_data == backend._ffi.NULL:
-                    backend._consume_errors()
-                    raise ValueError(
-                        "The {} extension is invalid and can't be "
-                        "parsed".format(oid)
-                    )
+                    if not oid in [ExtensionOID.OCSP_NO_CHECK]:
+                        backend._consume_errors()
+                        raise ValueError(
+                            "The {} extension is invalid and can't be "
+                            "parsed".format(oid)
+                        )

                 value = handler(backend, ext_data)
                 extensions.append(x509.Extension(oid, critical, value))
```

A sample certificate in attached.
[ftp.gijonfilmfestival.com-cer.zip](https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/files/4332411/ftp.gijonfilmfestival.com-cer.zip)

items.title: Backend._cipher_registry breaks inheritance
items.body:
I want to subclass AES and TripleDES, so that my child classes keep all the good stuff and also know certain codings specified in obscure standards or proprietary command sets. Here's a minimal test case showing my problem...

This works:

	from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.cmac import CMAC
	from cryptography.hazmat.backends import default_backend

	from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.ciphers.algorithms import AES

	cm = CMAC(AES(b'asdfghjklqwertyu'), default_backend())

This fails:

	from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.cmac import CMAC
	from cryptography.hazmat.backends import default_backend

	from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.ciphers import algorithms

	class AES(algorithms.AES):
		pass

	cm = CMAC(AES(b'asdfghjklqwertyu'), default_backend())

With:

	Traceback (most recent call last):
	  File "C:/bin/Python38/min_test_fail.py", line 9, in <module>
		cm = CMAC(AES(b'asdfghjklqwertyu'), default_backend())
	  File "C:\bin\Python38\lib\site-packages\cryptography\hazmat\primitives\cmac.py", line 31, in __init__
		self._ctx = self._backend.create_cmac_ctx(self._algorithm)
	  File "C:\bin\Python38\lib\site-packages\cryptography\hazmat\backends\openssl\backend.py", line 724, in create_cmac_ctx
		return _CMACContext(self, algorithm)
	  File "C:\bin\Python38\lib\site-packages\cryptography\hazmat\backends\openssl\cmac.py", line 19, in __init__
		raise UnsupportedAlgorithm("This backend does not support CMAC.",
	cryptography.exceptions.UnsupportedAlgorithm: This backend does not support CMAC.

Diagnosis:

To determine whether an algorithm supports a mode, in the case AES and CMAC, Backend looks up them up in its _cipher_registry, which is a dict keyed on tuples of (type(algorithm), type(mode)). My subclass is capable of supporting CMAC, but of course it's not in _cipher_registry, so the lookup fails and Backend rejects the operation.

I can fix it by putting my subclass in the same places as the base:

	from cryptography.hazmat.backends import default_backend
	backend = default_backend()

	def cryptography_lib_cipher_inhert(base, subclass):
		for cipher, mode in list(backend._cipher_registry):
			if cipher ==  base:
				backend._cipher_registry[subclass, mode] = backend._cipher_registry[base, mode]

	cryptography_lib_cipher_inhert(algorithms.AES, AES)

Great, now my self-tests all pass again. But of course I know what that leading underscore in _cipher_registry means. As a client, I should not be messing with the library's private variables.

I think the lookup should be re-worked to respect inheritance.

My version info:

	I:\>py
	Python 3.8.2 (tags/v3.8.2:7b3ab59, Feb 25 2020, 23:03:10) [MSC v.1916 64 bit (AMD64)] on win32
	Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.

	I:\>py -m pip install --upgrade cryptography
	Requirement already up-to-date: cryptography in c:\bin\python38\lib\site-packages (2.8)
	Requirement already satisfied, skipping upgrade: cffi!=1.11.3,>=1.8 in c:\bin\python38\lib\site-packages (from cryptography) (1.13.2)
	Requirement already satisfied, skipping upgrade: six>=1.4.1 in c:\bin\python38\lib\site-packages (from cryptography) (1.13.0)
	Requirement already satisfied, skipping upgrade: pycparser in c:\bin\python38\lib\site-packages (from cffi!=1.11.3,>=1.8->cryptography) (2.19)

items.title: TypeError when calling asdict() on a dataclass containing Certificates
items.body:
* Versions: Python 3.7.4 with cryptography 2.8.
* How you installed cryptography: via a Pipfile in my project

I am using Python 3.7's dataclasses to pass around data, including certificates parsed using `cryptography.x509.load_pem_x509_certificate()`. The dataclass module has a utility function called `asdict()` which turns a dataclass into a Python dictionary with the same fields (https://docs.python.org/3/library/dataclasses.html#dataclasses.asdict).

When calling `asdict()` on a dataclass instance that contains a Certificate, it crashes. The fix I found was to add a `__deepcopy__()` method to the Certificate class (specifically `cryptography.hazmat.backends.openssl.x509._Certificate`).

I don't know if the lack of support for `__deepcopy__()` is by design or not. If not I'd be willing to create a pull request with the fix (but I don't really understand all the implications of adding the `__deepcopy__()` method to this class).

### Steps to reproduce:

The following file contains a test case that will trigger the crash and a test case with the fix:

```
from dataclasses import dataclass, asdict
from pathlib import Path

from cryptography.hazmat.backends import default_backend
from cryptography.hazmat.backends.openssl.x509 import _Certificate
from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.serialization import Encoding
from cryptography.x509 import Certificate, load_pem_x509_certificate


# Any PEM certificate will work
path_to_a_cert = Path(__file__).absolute().parent / ".." / ".." / "certificates" / "github.com.pem"
certificate = load_pem_x509_certificate(path_to_a_cert.read_bytes(), default_backend())


@dataclass
class ClassThatContainsCertificates:
    certificate: Certificate


class TestDataclassWithCertificate:

    def test_crashes(self):
        value = ClassThatContainsCertificates(certificate=certificate)

        # It crashes here
        value_as_dict = asdict(value)

    def test_succeeds(self):
        # Monkeypatch to add __deepcopy__() to cryptography.hazmat.backends.openssl.x509._Certificate
        def _deepcopy_method_for_x509_certificate(inner_self, memo: str) -> Certificate:
            return load_pem_x509_certificate(inner_self.public_bytes(Encoding.PEM), backend=default_backend())

        _Certificate.__deepcopy__ = _deepcopy_method_for_x509_certificate

        value = ClassThatContainsCertificates(certificate=certificate)

        # No crash
        value_as_dict = asdict(value)
        
``` 

The stack trace for the crash is the following:

``` 
tests\test_crash.py:21 (TestDataclassWithCertificate.test_crashes)
self = <tests.plugins_tests.certificate_info.test_crash.TestDataclassWithCertificate object at 0x00000211DBD8F348>

    def test_crashes(self):
        value = ClassThatContainsCertificates(certificate=certificate)
    
        # It crashes here
>       value_as_dict = asdict(value)

tests\test_crash.py:26: 
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _
..\..\..\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python37\Lib\dataclasses.py:1044: in asdict
    return _asdict_inner(obj, dict_factory)
..\..\..\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python37\Lib\dataclasses.py:1051: in _asdict_inner
    value = _asdict_inner(getattr(obj, f.name), dict_factory)
..\..\..\AppData\Local\Programs\Python\Python37\Lib\dataclasses.py:1085: in _asdict_inner
    return copy.deepcopy(obj)
..\..\..\.virtualenvs\sslyze-VjIqHxGI\lib\copy.py:180: in deepcopy
    y = _reconstruct(x, memo, *rv)
..\..\..\.virtualenvs\sslyze-VjIqHxGI\lib\copy.py:280: in _reconstruct
    state = deepcopy(state, memo)
..\..\..\.virtualenvs\sslyze-VjIqHxGI\lib\copy.py:150: in deepcopy
    y = copier(x, memo)
..\..\..\.virtualenvs\sslyze-VjIqHxGI\lib\copy.py:240: in _deepcopy_dict
    y[deepcopy(key, memo)] = deepcopy(value, memo)
..\..\..\.virtualenvs\sslyze-VjIqHxGI\lib\copy.py:180: in deepcopy
    y = _reconstruct(x, memo, *rv)
..\..\..\.virtualenvs\sslyze-VjIqHxGI\lib\copy.py:280: in _reconstruct
    state = deepcopy(state, memo)
..\..\..\.virtualenvs\sslyze-VjIqHxGI\lib\copy.py:150: in deepcopy
    y = copier(x, memo)
..\..\..\.virtualenvs\sslyze-VjIqHxGI\lib\copy.py:240: in _deepcopy_dict
    y[deepcopy(key, memo)] = deepcopy(value, memo)
_ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _ _

x = <CompiledFFI object at 0x00000211DAC9D318>
memo = {2275709052744: <cryptography.hazmat.bindings.openssl.binding.Binding object at 0x00000211DBD8F7C8>, 2275709053768: <c...binding': <cryptography.hazmat.bindings.openssl.binding.Binding object at 0x00000211DBD8F7C8>}, 2275725107912: {}, ...}
_nil = []

    def deepcopy(x, memo=None, _nil=[]):
        """Deep copy operation on arbitrary Python objects.
    
        See the module's __doc__ string for more info.
        """
    
        if memo is None:
            memo = {}
    
        d = id(x)
        y = memo.get(d, _nil)
        if y is not _nil:
            return y
    
        cls = type(x)
    
        copier = _deepcopy_dispatch.get(cls)
        if copier:
            y = copier(x, memo)
        else:
            try:
                issc = issubclass(cls, type)
            except TypeError: # cls is not a class (old Boost; see SF #502085)
                issc = 0
            if issc:
                y = _deepcopy_atomic(x, memo)
            else:
                copier = getattr(x, "__deepcopy__", None)
                if copier:
                    y = copier(memo)
                else:
                    reductor = dispatch_table.get(cls)
                    if reductor:
                        rv = reductor(x)
                    else:
                        reductor = getattr(x, "__reduce_ex__", None)
                        if reductor:
>                           rv = reductor(4)
E                           TypeError: can't pickle CompiledFFI objects

items.title: Doc mistake in example.
items.body:
Example for extentions [here](https://cryptography.io/en/latest/x509/reference/#cryptography.x509.Certificate.extensions) contains errors:

` <Extension(oid=<ObjectIdentifier(oid=2.5.29.15, name=keyUsage)>, critical=True, value=<KeyUsage(digital_signature=False, content_commitment=False, key_encipherment=False, data_encipherment=False, key_agreement=False, key_cert_sign=True, crl_sign=True, encipher_only=None, decipher_only=None)>`

Last two parameters should also be False, as per documentation. Otherwise certificate creation fails.

items.title: openssl.Backend.load_der_ocsp_response() failing to load complex response
items.body:
* Versions of Python, ``cryptography``, ``cffi``, ``pip``, and ``setuptools``
  you're using
```
Name: cryptography
Version: 2.8
---
Name: cffi
Version: 1.11.5
---
Name: pip
Version: 18.1
---
Name: setuptools
Version: 40.8.0
```

* How you installed ``cryptography``
`pip install cryptography --upgrade`

* Clear steps for reproducing your bug
Code:
```python
from cryptography.hazmat.backends.openssl.backend import backend as x509_openssl_backend
ocsp_response_der = open('ocsp-army.deps.mil-resp.der', 'rb').read()
x509_openssl_backend.load_der_ocsp_response(ocsp_response_der )
```

Error:
```
    ocsp_resp = x509_openssl_backend.load_der_ocsp_response(r.content)
  File "/usr/local/lib64/python3.7/site-packages/cryptography/hazmat/backends/openssl/backend.py", line 1531, in load_der_ocsp_response
    return _OCSPResponse(self, response)
  File "/usr/local/lib64/python3.7/site-packages/cryptography/hazmat/backends/openssl/ocsp.py", line 106, in __init__
    self._backend._lib.OCSP_resp_count(self._basic) == 1
  File "/usr/local/lib64/python3.7/site-packages/cryptography/hazmat/backends/openssl/backend.py", line 131, in openssl_assert
    return binding._openssl_assert(self._lib, ok)
  File "/usr/local/lib64/python3.7/site-packages/cryptography/hazmat/bindings/openssl/binding.py", line 78, in _openssl_assert
    errors_with_text
cryptography.exceptions.InternalError: Unknown OpenSSL error. This error is commonly encountered when another library is not cleaning up the OpenSSL error stack.
```

The specific OCSP-response file is attached as a Zip-file.
[ocsp-army.deps.mil-resp.zip](https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/files/4239418/ocsp-army.deps.mil-resp.zip)

* Additional information:
Running:
```
$ openssl ocsp -respin ocsp-army.deps.mil-resp.der -text
```
will produce correct and expected output without errors.

This error is highly data-dependant and very reproducible. For some other data, the Python code works. For this particular data everything explodes. My thinking is, this data is worst-case-scenario. The OCSP-response has all kinds of extensions in it.

items.title: x509.Name.rfc4514_string() returns RDNs in wrong order
items.body:
Hi everyone,

I think the `rfc4514_string()` function of `x509.Name` should return the RDNs in reversed order compared to their 'real' order in i.e. a certificate, because RFC4514 states in section 2.1:

> Otherwise, the output consists of the string encodings of each
> RelativeDistinguishedName in the RDNSequence (according to Section
> 2.2), starting with the last element of the sequence and moving
> backwards toward the first.

I.e. I would expect that a x509.CertificateSigningRequest's subject translates into a string representation (according to RFC4514) like
`"CN=elephant,O=serengeti,C=TZ"`.

The CSR can i.e. be created using OpenSSL:
`openssl req -new -newkey rsa:1024 -keyout test.key -nodes -out test.csr -subj "/C=TZ/O=serengeti/CN=elephant"`.

However doing
```python
from cryptography import x509
from cryptography.hazmat.backends import default_backend

with open('test.csr') as f:
    csr = f.read().encode('ascii')

csr = x509.load_pem_x509_csr(csr, default_backend())
print(csr.subject.rfc4514_string())
```
gives `C=TZ,O=serengeti,CN=elephant`.

The issue - if I understand the RFC correctly and it even is one - is probably located here: https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/blob/master/src/cryptography/x509/name.py#L221 . Inserting a `reversed(...)` should fix it.
Would be great if someone could share her/his opinion on this, and if we all agree I could create a PR. However there is not much point in creating a PR to add a single word, I guess ...

items.title: OpenSSL with -DOPENSSL_NO_SRTP errors when initializing backend
items.body:
When building OpenSSL with the -DOPENSSL_NO_SRTP flag, pyca/cryptography fails to initialize the default backend.

I built OpenSSL against OpenSSL_1_1_1-stable commit (a9a8863b7), with the following config:

```
./config --prefix=/home/ubuntu/openssl/build --openssldir=/home/ubuntu/openssl/build -DOPENSSL_NO_SRTP
make clean; make
make install
```

Then I get the following error:

```
(venv) ubuntu@ip-172-31-21-1:~/openssl/openssl$ python
Python 3.6.9 (default, Nov  7 2019, 10:44:02) 
[GCC 8.3.0] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> from cryptography.hazmat.backends import default_backend
>>> default_backend()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/home/ubuntu/openssl/cryptography/src/cryptography/hazmat/backends/__init__.py", line 15, in default_backend
    from cryptography.hazmat.backends.openssl.backend import backend
  File "/home/ubuntu/openssl/cryptography/src/cryptography/hazmat/backends/openssl/__init__.py", line 7, in <module>
    from cryptography.hazmat.backends.openssl.backend import backend
  File "/home/ubuntu/openssl/cryptography/src/cryptography/hazmat/backends/openssl/backend.py", line 75, in <module>
    from cryptography.hazmat.bindings.openssl import binding
  File "/home/ubuntu/openssl/cryptography/src/cryptography/hazmat/bindings/openssl/binding.py", line 16, in <module>
    from cryptography.hazmat.bindings._openssl import ffi, lib
ImportError: /home/ubuntu/openssl/cryptography/src/cryptography/hazmat/bindings/_openssl.abi3.so: symbol SSL_CTX_set_tlsext_use_srtp version OPENSSL_1_1_0 not defined in file libssl.so.1.1 with link time reference
```
I'm running against head of cryptography (commit c0dbbb52). 

Using the same setup, and removing the `-DOPENSSL_NO_SRTP` flag to `config` I'm able to initialize the backend as expected.

Os
```
$ uname -a
Linux ip-172-31-21-1 4.15.0-1058-aws #60-Ubuntu SMP Wed Jan 15 22:35:20 UTC 2020 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

Python version:
```
$ python --version
Python 3.6.9
```

According this link [1], there are a few things that can be disabled in OpenSSL, and if you'll accept this as a bug, I'd be happy to create some script that goes through all the permutations of flags to find out what breaks when this project tries to use it.

[1] https://stackoverflow.com/questions/7827836/build-openssl-with-just-rsa-and-aes#7828924

items.title: [Question] DHParameters with custom p and g
items.body:
Hey,

is there a way to use DH with this library but choose p and g yourself?

All I can find is a way to derive the key given the public numbers, as stated in the [docs](https://cryptography.io/en/latest/hazmat/primitives/asymmetric/dh/#cryptography.hazmat.primitives.asymmetric.dh.DHPublicNumbers):
```python
pn = dh.DHParameterNumbers(p, g)
parameters = pn.parameters(default_backend())
peer_public_numbers = dh.DHPublicNumbers(y, pn)
peer_public_key = peer_public_numbers.public_key(default_backend())
```

However I'd rather generate private keys myself. Essentially I need something like this:

```python
parameters = dh.generate_parameters(generator=2, p=0xf00, backend=default_backend())
```

I don't care if this is bad in terms of security, this is rather educational. Obviously it is very easy to do this without this library, however I was wondering if I could still utilize it.

Thanks

items.title: Support larger lock sizes for `PKCS#7` and `ANSI X9.23`
Possible bug in AES-GCM encryption/decryption
items.body:
Encrypting files with AES-GCM is raising an error when I try to verify, and I'm utterly stumped on how to fix it. This is a trimmed version which reproduces the error, and `hashlib` is included to check input/output data.

Running `cryptography` 2.8 and python 3.7 on windows 10 and CPython.

```python
from cryptography.hazmat.backends import default_backend
from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.ciphers import Cipher, algorithms, modes
from hashlib import sha256


with open('test.txt', 'rb') as infile:
    aes = Cipher(algorithms.AES(b'legoroojlegorooj'), modes.GCM(b'legoroojlegorooj'), default_backend()).encryptor()
    aes.authenticate_additional_data(b'')

    infile.seek(0, 2)
    length = infile.tell()
    chunks = ((length - (length % 256)) // 256) + 1
    infile.seek(0, 0)
    
    with open('out_example.txt', 'wb+') as outfile:
        for i in range(1, chunks+1):
            data = aes.update(infile.read(256))
            outfile.write(data)
        data = aes.finalize()
        outfile.write(data)
        outfile.seek(0, 0)
        outfile.write(b'legoroojlegorooj')
        outfile.write(aes.tag)

    f = open('out_example.txt', 'rb')
    f.seek(32)
    print(sha256(f.read()).hexdigest())

with open('out_example.txt', 'rb+') as infile:
    infile.seek(0, 2)
    length = infile.tell() - 32
    chunks = ((length - (length % 256)) // 256) + 1
    infile.seek(0, 0)
    nonce = infile.read(16)
    gcm_tag = infile.read(16)
    
    aes = Cipher(
        algorithms.AES(b'legoroojlegorooj'),
        modes.GCM(b'legoroojlegorooj', tag=gcm_tag),
        default_backend()
    ).decryptor()
    
    aes.authenticate_additional_data(b'')
    hf = sha256()
    
    with open('outfile.txt', 'wb+') as outfile:
        for i in range(1, chunks+1):
            data = infile.read(256)
            hf.update(data)
            outfile.write(aes.update(data))
        print(hf.hexdigest())
        try:
            outfile.write(aes.finalize())
        except Exception as e:
            raise e
```
The contents of `test.txt` is available here. https://gist.github.com/Legorooj/dcb73bfead1663d901e95bbe15d97b2c

items.title: 'cryptography.hazmat': No module named 'cryptography.hazmat'; 'cryptography' is not a package`
items.body:
I'm trying to execute the examples provided in documentation, but getting this error. 

To make it simple, I tried just to import the library, but couldn't do it. It happens in Windows 10 and Ubuntu. 

with: `import cryptography` or

`from cryptography.hazmat.backends import default_backend`

I get the error:

`ModuleNotFoundError: No module named 'cryptography.hazmat'; 'cryptography' is not a package`

pip freeze: (pip 9.0.1)
setuptools (39.0.1)

```
astroid==2.3.3
autopep8==1.4.4
cffi==1.13.2
cryptography==2.8
isort==4.3.21
lazy-object-proxy==1.4.3
mccabe==0.6.1
pkg-resources==0.0.0
pycodestyle==2.5.0
pycparser==2.19
pylint==2.4.4
pyOpenSSL==19.1.0
six==1.13.0
typed-ast==1.4.0
wrapt==1.11.2
```
Many answers say to check for libssll to be install. I've done:

`sudo apt-get install libssl-dev libffi-dev `

But I still cannot load the library.

Let me know if providing other details to you, I could be more helpfull.

Thank you.

items.title: Installation - Within Splunk python interpreter
items.body:
Version of python: 2.7.15 
Cffi: 1.13.2 
Cryptography: 2.8 

I have a custom TA that is not handling additional Python modules.
I have already linked with the Scientific Computing for Python (exec_anaconda) headers to use numpy, scipy,etc libraries.
However, I'm also using 'cryptography' to leverage a fernet routine to encrypt and salt a stored password to encrypt a 3rd party plaintext authentication routine.
in the current 'bin' path of the TA is the cryptography directory from 'site-packages'
Example Python Stub
---
import exec_anaconda
exec_anaconda.exec_anaconda()
import os
import sys
import cryptography
print "Loads success"
#Use fernet package - FAILS
from cryptography.fernet import Fernet
----
Also tried using 'sys.path.append('system/local/site-package/path') as well to call from OS python with no luck
Also tried including cffi, enum, chardet, etc in the local path as well. 

Traceback (most recent call last):
   File "Stub_sci_test.py", line 33, in <module>
       from cryptography.fernet import Fernet 
  File "/opt/splunk/etc/apps/TA_Mine/bin/cryptography/fernet.py", line 17, in <module>
       from cryptography.hazmat.primitives import hashes, padding 
  File "/opt/splunk/etc/apps/TA_Mine/bin/cryptography/hazmat/primitives/padding.py", line 13, in <module> 
    from cryptography.hazamat.bindings._padding import lib 
ImportError: No module named _cffi_backend

items.title: Cannot build wheel on Redhat 5.6 due to 'unrecognized command'
items.body:
I try to build wheel of cryptography-2.8 on Redhat 5.6 i686 and it fails due to:
`cc1: error: unrecognized command line option "-Wno-error=sign-conversion"`

Versions I use:
Red Hat Enterprise Linux Server release 5.6 (Tikanga)
gcc 4.1.2
Python 2.7.8
pip 19.0.1
setuptools 40.6.3
cffi 2.19

When I try to run `python setup.py bdist_wheel` I get the following error:

> root@host-ci033 (Redhat 5.6) ➜  cryptography-2.8 python setup.py bdist_wheel
> running bdist_wheel
> running build
> running build_py
> running egg_info
> writing requirements to src/cryptography.egg-info/requires.txt
> writing src/cryptography.egg-info/PKG-INFO
> writing top-level names to src/cryptography.egg-info/top_level.txt
> writing dependency_links to src/cryptography.egg-info/dependency_links.txt
> reading manifest file 'src/cryptography.egg-info/SOURCES.txt'
> reading manifest template 'MANIFEST.in'
> no previously-included directories found matching 'docs/_build'
> warning: no previously-included files found matching 'vectors'
> warning: no previously-included files matching '*' found under directory 'vectors'
> warning: no previously-included files found matching 'azure-pipelines.yml'
> warning: no previously-included files found matching '.azure-pipelines'
> warning: no previously-included files found matching '.travis.yml'
> warning: no previously-included files found matching '.travis'
> warning: no previously-included files matching '*' found under directory '.azure-pipelines'
> warning: no previously-included files matching '*' found under directory '.travis'
> warning: no previously-included files found matching 'release.py'
> warning: no previously-included files found matching '.coveragerc'
> warning: no previously-included files found matching 'codecov.yml'
> warning: no previously-included files found matching 'dev-requirements.txt'
> warning: no previously-included files found matching 'rtd-requirements.txt'
> warning: no previously-included files found matching 'tox.ini'
> writing manifest file 'src/cryptography.egg-info/SOURCES.txt'
> running build_ext
> generating cffi module 'build/temp.linux-i686-2.7/_padding.c'
> already up-to-date
> generating cffi module 'build/temp.linux-i686-2.7/_constant_time.c'
> already up-to-date
> generating cffi module 'build/temp.linux-i686-2.7/_openssl.c'
> already up-to-date
> building '_openssl' extension
> gcc -pthread -fno-strict-aliasing -I/root/python/include -I/root/python/include/gnutls -I/root/python/include/graphviz -I/root/python/include/libexslt -I/root/python/include/libxml2 -I/root/python/include/libxslt -I/root/python/include/ncurses -I/root/python/include/openssl -I/root/python/include/readline -I/root/python/include/sasl -I/root/python/lib/libffi-3.2.1/include -DNDEBUG -g -fwrapv -O3 -Wall -Wstrict-prototypes -fPIC -I/root/python/include/python2.7 -c build/temp.linux-i686-2.7/_openssl.c -o build/temp.linux-i686-2.7/build/temp.linux-i686-2.7/_openssl.o -Wconversion -Wno-error=sign-conversion
> cc1: error: unrecognized command line option "-Wno-error=sign-conversion"
> error: command 'gcc' failed with exit status 1

Probably the flag `-Wno-error=sign-conversion` is not supported on old gcc versions like the Redhat 5.6 has.

items.title: undefined symbol: pthread_atfork in _openssl.abi3.so
items.body:
Found on Python 3.7.4, with cryptography 2.7, pip 19.2.3, cffi 1.12.3, setuptools 41.2.0 but most likely all versions are affected.

Installed with `pip install --prefix=/tmp/crypto  --no-deps  --ignore-installed  --no-build-isolation  .`

Target architecture is Power9 (ppcle64) which is important due to a change in pthread/GLIBC.

The issue is caused by a wrong/missing order of `-lpthread` when linking the shared library. Full details can be found at https://ryanarn.blogspot.com/2011/07/curious-case-of-pthreadatfork-on.html

In fact it seems that phtread is not even linked explicitely:

```
gcc
-shared
-L/sw/installed/libffi/3.2.1-GCCcore-8.2.0/lib64
-L/sw/installed/libffi/3.2.1-GCCcore-8.2.0/lib

items.title: Use manylinux2014 to get aarch64/ppc64le support
items.body:
Manylinux2014 image got released some time ago. One of things it brings is support for !x86 architectures.

Cryptography is using Travis CI so two things can be joined and used to generate wheel files for aarch64 and ppc64le architectures.

Amount of software installed to be able to run 'pip install cryptography' would be cut. Also install times would be nicer.

items.title: Best of the lot, but weak in 2017 in Asymmetric Crypto
items.body: https://www.ieee-security.org/TC/SP2017/papers/161.pdf published in 2017 shows this library is a fantastic choice for symmetric crypto tasks, but at the time was a bit confusing for asymmetric crypto. Have the identified issues already been resolved?

items.title: 'Type[...] has no attribute "Raw"'
items.body:
With following example code in `test.py`
    
    from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.serialization   import Encoding, PublicFormat
    from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.asymmetric.x448 import X448PrivateKey
    
    private_key = X448PrivateKey.generate()
    
    public_key = private_key.public_key().public_bytes(encoding=Encoding.Raw,
                                                       format=PublicFormat.Raw)  # type: bytes
    
    peer_public_key = X448PrivateKey.generate().public_key()
    
    shared_key = private_key.exchange(peer_public_key)
    
Running `$ python3.7 -m mypy test.py`

Shows warnings

`test.py:7: error: "Type[Encoding]" has no attribute "Raw"`
`test.py:8: error: "Type[PublicFormat]" has no attribute "Raw"`

Is this a typeshed issue, mypy issue, or does the library have a bug?


**Python version**:
`Python 3.7.5 (default, Nov 20 2019, 09:21:52)`
`GCC 9.2.1 20191008] on linux`

**cryptography version**: `2.8`

**mypy version**: `0.740`

items.title: Install failure on manylinux1_686
items.body:
Installing `cryptography` on [manylinux1 686 docker image](quay.io/pypa/manylinux1_i686) fails. This was working well previously but it started failing from yesterday (Nov 18)

### How to reproduce
```
$ docker run -it quay.io/pypa/manylinux1_i686 /bin/bash
# yum install -y openssl-devel
# /opt/_internal/cpython-3.8.0/bin/pip install --upgrade pip
# /opt/_internal/cpython-3.8.0/bin/pip install cryptography==2.8
```

items.title: Support deeper ed25519 functionality (that can do key blinding)
items.body:
Hello cryptography people!

This is a request for deeper ed25519 support in the Python hazmat crypto lib. The goal is to be able to implement key blinding primitives [like the ones used](https://gitweb.torproject.org/torspec.git/tree/proposals/224-rend-spec-ng.txt#n2106) by [v3 Tor onion services](https://gitweb.torproject.org/torspec.git/tree/proposals/224-rend-spec-ng.txt#n2135) (also see [here](https://www-users.cs.umn.edu/~hoppernj/basic-proof.pdf) for relevant proof). The same techniques AFAIK are used to do _hierarchically derived deterministic wallets_ in various cryptocurrency schemes.

***

In particular the missing functionality is:
- Support the `(a, RH)` private key format as described by [Brian Warner](https://blog.mozilla.org/warner/2011/11/29/ed25519-keys/), which allows us to blind the privkey scalar `a' = blind(a)` and still compute a signature with `a'` [which is not possible](https://trac.torproject.org/projects/tor/ticket/28123#comment:4) with the `(k, A)` private key format that hazmat uses.
- Support additional ed25519 primitives like:
  - Ability to do scalar multiplication on the 25519 curve
  - Ability to decode and encode points on the curve
  - Ability to check if a point is on the curve

***

For now, in our Python code [we are using](https://gitweb.torproject.org/user/atagar/stem.git/tree/stem/descriptor/slow_ed25519.py?h=hsv3) djb's super slow ed25519 implementation (which exposes the required primitives), plus the [required key blinding](https://gitweb.torproject.org/user/atagar/stem.git/tree/stem/descriptor/hsv3_crypto.py?h=hsv3#n19) code and then[ we wrap it with a fragile type-ducked key layer](https://gitweb.torproject.org/user/atagar/stem.git/tree/stem/descriptor/hsv3_crypto.py?h=hsv3#n52) that emulates a hazmat key. All in all [it's not so much fun](https://trac.torproject.org/projects/tor/ticket/31777) particularly since it's incredibly slow.

For comparison in our core C code, we are using the ed25519 donna code, [slightly modded](https://github.com/torproject/tor/blob/master/src/ext/ed25519/donna/ed25519_tor.c#L257) to support our blind key primitives and the [custom key format](https://github.com/torproject/tor/blob/master/src/ext/ed25519/donna/ed25519_tor.c#L214).

***

If the Hazmat lib is not designed to do such low level operations, it would be great if you could suggest alternative approaches for what we are trying to do.

Thanks!

items.title: Fails to build when OpenSSL is build without Certificate Transparency (CT) support
items.body:
cryptography fails to build with compiler errors when compiled against an OpenSSL that has Certificate Transparency (CT) disabled.

Build warnings/error summary:
 * Several: `error: use of undeclared identifier  'SCT_*'`
 * Several: `error: use of undeclared identifier 'CT_LOG_*'`
 * Several: `warning: implicit declaration of function 'SCT_*' is invalid in C99`
 * Final error:

```
build/temp.freebsd-13.0-CURRENT-amd64-3.7/_openssl.c:33416:8: error: unknown type name 'ct_log_entry_type_t'
static ct_log_entry_type_t _cffi_d_SCT_get_log_entry_type(SCT const * x0)
       ^
```

Reproduction Environment:

 * Operating System: FreeBSD 13.0-CURRENT #3 r354143 (amd64)
   * FreeBSD clang version 9.0.0 (tags/RELEASE_900/final 372316) (based on LLVM 9.0.0)
 * OpenSSL: 1.1.1d-freebsd 10 Sep 2019 (via ports, with `CT` option **disabled**) 
   * `./configure: --openssldir=/usr/local/openssl  --prefix=/usr/local no-ct `
 * Python 2.7.17 / 3.7.5
 * cryptography: 2.8 (PyPI sdist)

Full build log attached:

[cryptography-2.8-no-CT-build-failure.log](https://github.com/pyca/cryptography/files/3855123/cryptography-2.8-no-CT-build-failure.log)

items.title: Generalized N way ECDH Multi Party Computation key exchange protocol
items.body:
I'm trying to create a code showing Elliptic Curve Diffie–Hellman key agreement with more than two parties: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Diffie%E2%80%93Hellman_key_exchange

I'm stuck after exchanging a key, I get a `shared key` which is a bytes value.
Is it possible to load this `shared_key` as a new public key?

Here is the beginning of my work:
```python
from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.asymmetric import ec
from cryptography.hazmat.backends import default_backend

alice = ec.generate_private_key(ec.SECP384R1(), default_backend())
bob = ec.generate_private_key(ec.SECP384R1(), default_backend())
carol = ec.generate_private_key(ec.SECP384R1(), default_backend())

# Bob computes (ga)b = gab and sends it to Carol.
ab = bob.exchange(ec.ECDH(), alice.public_key())

# Carol computes (gab)c = gabc and uses it as her secret.
abc = carol.exchange(ec.ECDH(), ab) # will fail as ab is not a public key object

# Carol computes (gb)c = gbc and sends it to Alice.
bc = carol.exchange(ec.ECDH(), bob.public_key())

# Alice computes (gbc)a = gbca = gabc and uses it as her secret.
bca = alice.exchange(ec.ECDH(), bc)

# Alice computes (gc)a = gca and sends it to Bob.
ca = carol.exchange(ec.ECDH(), alice.public_key())

# Bob computes (gca)b = gcab = gabc and uses it as his secret.
cab = bob.exchange(ec.ECDH(), ca)

print(abc == bca)
print(bca == cab)
print(abc == cab)

print(abc)
```

I think I'm missing something very simple.

items.title: Support AF_ALG in-kernel cryptography
items.body:
https://www.pythonsheets.com/notes/python-socket.html

```
$ python3 aes-gcm.py
total cost time: 15.317010641098022. [AF_ALG]
total cost time: 50.256704807281494. [cryptography]
```

Thanks to Python3.6 `socket.sendmsg_afalg()` function.

items.title: Drop support for some versions of LibreSSL
items.body: Currently our matrix of LibreSSL version support grows unbounded. We should drop support for one or two of them.

items.title: RSA public key verify
items.body:
I need to use SmileID API. Requests are signed with signature by public key, and response signature must be verified.
The algorithm for calculate outgoing signature
```

1. Create a timestamp
2. Join the integer value of your int Partner ID to the timestamp using a semi-colon in the format 5:[timestamp]
3. Create a SHA256 hash of the string created in Step 2
4. Public Key encrypt the hash using your Base 64 decoded API key. We encourage that you utilise the base 64 encoded version and then decode the api key on your server to public encrypt the hash, however, should you choose to use the the decoded version of your api key, you will also find it here
5. Base64 encode the encrypted hash
6. Finally join the the encrypted hash to  the unencrypted hash using the "|" character
```

Public key is used to verify the signature of response coming from smileid server. I have problems with it. I tried to use:
```
public_key.verify(
    base64.b64decode(encrypted),
    hashed.encode('ascii'),
    padding.PKCS1v15(),
    # hashes.SHA256(), not sure but its positional argument
)
```
It mismatch by such calculation. Maybe I am just using wrong your function? Can you help please?
Code from Ruby that should work (from documentation):
```
> Calculating an incoming signature:

api_key = "TgorWTFHTG5NL2hEUU5aM3M2ZWJCUndWZGR1aTRLejNCTGZ2RkJwWis1Myty="
partner_id = "001"
timestamp = body["timestamp"]
hash = Digest::SHA256.hexdigest([partner_id.to_i, timestamp].join(":"))
encrypted, hashed = body["sec_key"].split("|")
success = OpenSSL::PKey::RSA.new(Base64.decode64(api_key)).public_decrypt(Base64.decode64(encrypted)) == hash && hash == hashed
## success should equal true
```
Is there a way for public_decrypt?

items.title: python3 setup.py sdist bdist_wheel, AIX and not gcc
items.body:
Building "cryptography" when not using gcc fails (on AIX) with a message something like this:
  xlc_r -DNDEBUG -O -I/opt/include -O2 -qmaxmem=-1 -qarch=pwr5 -q64 -I/opt/include -O2 -qmaxmem=-1 -qarch=pwr5 -q64 -I/opt/include/python3.6m -c build/temp.AIX.6106.1043.64-3.6/_openssl.c -o build/temp.AIX.6106.1043.64-3.6/build/temp.AIX.6106.1043.64-3.6/_openssl.o -Wconversion -Wno-error=sign-conversion
  xlc_r: 1501-210 (S) command option Wconversion contains an incorrect subargument
  error: command 'xlc_r' failed with exit status 40

In the message above - ignore xlc_r - note that the compiler is not gcc and the gcc flags -Wconversion and -Wno-error=sign-conversion are not recognized.

I'll submit a PR - once I figure out how to look up the compiler name that will be used. For now my quick hack is to modify:

--- ./src/_cffi_src/build_openssl.py    2019-10-31 13:56:43.000000000 +0000
+++ ./src/_cffi_src/build_openssl.py.new        2019-10-31 13:36:58.000000000 +0000
@@ -46,7 +46,7 @@
      When we drop support for CRYPTOGRAPHY_OPENSSL_LESS_THAN_110 we can
      revisit this.
      """
-     if platform not in ["win32", "hp-ux11", "sunos5"]:
+     if platform not in ["aix6", "aix7", "aix", "win32", "hp-ux11", "sunos5"]:
          return ["-Wconversion", "-Wno-error=sign-conversion"]
      else:
          return []

items.title: EllipticCurvePrivateKey is missing docs for curve attribute
items.body: I'm not sure when this attribute was added but it seems to be missing from the documentation.

items.title: AttributeError: 'function' object has no attribute 'sign'
items.body:
**this error** 

```
File "C:/Users/user/PycharmProjects/mycrypto/venv/myfile1.py", line 13, in signature_1
    sig = private_key.sign(message,padding.PSS( mgf=padding.MGF1(hashes.SHA256()),
AttributeError: 'function' object has no attribute 'sign'
```

  **Code:**
```
from cryptography.hazmat.backends import default_backend
from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.asymmetric import rsa
from cryptography.hazmat.primitives import hashes
from cryptography.hazmat.primitives.asymmetric import padding

def generate_keys():
    private_key = rsa.generate_private_key(public_exponent=65537, key_size=2048, backend=default_backend())
    public_key =private_key.public_key
    return private_key,public_key


def signature_1(message,private_key):
     sig = private_key.sign(message,padding.PSS( mgf=padding.MGF1(hashes.SHA256()),
                                                       salt_length=padding.PSS.MAX_LENGTH),hashes.SHA256())
     return sig

def verify(message,public_key):
    try:
     public_key.verify(signature,message,padding.PSS(mgf = padding.MGF1(hashes.SHA256()),
                                                    salt_length = padding.PSS.MAX_LENGTH),hashes.SHA256())
     return True

    except InvalidSignature :
     return False

if(__name__=='__main__'):
    pu,pr=generate_keys()
    print(pr)
    print(pu)
    message = b"this is message"
    sig = signature_1(message,pr)
    print(sig)

```
